occurrences.line_text: To doe, what euer he thought good or fit.
And of his owne vaine fancies thought did frame:
Yet spake she seldom, but thought more, the lesse she sed.
With great amazement, & his thought with wonder fild.
Thought best away me to remoue somewhere
For him to trouble she it thought vnfit,
And him to beare, she thought it thing too base.
And inly did afflict her pensiue thought,
Sith his own thought he knew most cleare from wite.
For that him selfe he thought from daunger free,
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
And stopt the bleeding straight, ere he it staunched thought.
He with him thought backe to returne againe:
Therefore some thought, that those braue imps were sowen
But day and night did vexe her carefull thought,
Withouten thought of shame or villeny,
Thought therewithall forthwith him to haue slaine,
Amongst so many foes, whom sure he thought
Ne secretly from thought of fell reuenge surceasse.
And to him leaping, vengeance thought to take
That none she worthie thought to be her fere,
But this coy Damzell thought contrariwize,
Vnder that villaines club, then surely thought
And with the second stroke, thought certainely
Thought sure haue pownded him to powder soft,
Long thus she fled, till that at last she thought
As each thought best to spend the lingring space.
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
Which Calidore perceiuing, thought it best
Thought sure t'auenge his grudge, & worke his foe great shame.
She in regard hereof refusde and thought vnfit.
Of griesly theeues, she thought her self in hell,
She thought it best, for shadow to pretend
There did they find, contrarie to their thought,
Sir Calidore him arm'd, as he thought best,
Had neuer ioyance felt, nor chearefull thought,
This daughter thought in wedlocke to haue bound
Which hauing thought long dead, she fyndes aliue,
Nor euer thought thing so vnworthily:
And raise my thoughts too humble and too vile,
Still flying from his thoughts and gealous feare;
He seemd in hart to harbour thoughts vnkind,
That rules mens wayes, and rules the thoughts of liuing wight.
Ne diuelish thoughts dismay thy constant spright.
That forst him lay his heauenly thoughts aside;
Or faultie thoughts continewd, as was fit;
O how great wonder would your thoughts deuoure,
All those were idle thoughts and fantasies,
And with vaine thoughts her falsed fancy vex:
She soundly slept, & carefull thoughts did quite assoile.
Her loue-sicke hart to other thoughts did steale;
A thousand thoughts she fashioned in her mind,
With such selfe-pleasing thoughts her wound she fed,
The baser wit, whose idle thoughts alway
But did his hart with bitter thoughts engore,
With hatefull thoughts to languish and to pine,
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
But rul'd her thoughts with goodly gouernement,
Those be vnquiet thoughts, that carefull minds inuade.
That inly feeds it selfe with thoughts vnkind,
And looser thoughts to lawfull bounds withdraw;
Of bitter thoughts, which deepe therein infixed lay.
Through thoughts aspyring to eternall fame.
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
Braue thoughts and noble deedes did euermore aspire.
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
Without discouerie of my thoughts pretence,
And fairely did dissemble her sad thoughts vnrest.
And sent her winged thoughts, more swift then wind,
With thousand thoughts feeding her fantasie,
And trampled downe in dust his thoughts disdained scorne.
That I nigh rauisht with rare thoughts delight,
And not in outward shows, but inward thoughts defynd.
Me no such cares nor combrous thoughts offend,
And many gealous thoughts conceiu'd in vaine,
All dewfull seruice voide of thoughts imp[u]re:
A thousand yong ones, which she dayly fed,
Ten thousand kindes of creatures, partly male
Who streight him rent in thousand peeces small,
And thousand other wayes, to bait his fleshly hookes.
In which ten thousand sorts of punishment
Curled with thousand adders venemous,
And thousand feends that doe them endlesse paine
For thousand times he so himselfe had drest,
In heauenly throne, where thousand Angels shine?
As did this knight twelue thousand dolours daunt,
And thousand thankes him yeelds for all his paine.
With thousand other sleights: for well he kend,
And thousand furies wait on wrathfull sword;
That speare is him enough to doen a thousand grone.
So faire, and thousand thousand times more faire
So faire, and thousand thousand times more faire
Me liefer were ten thousand deathes priefe,
To kindle his quencht fire, and thousand causes wrought.
She could deuise, and thousand waies inuent,
Would him haue rent in thousand peeces strayt:
And thousand Sar'zins foully donne to dye.
Thousand times fairer then her mortall hew,
For losse of thousand liues, to dye at her desire.
But thousand enemies about vs raue,
A thousand villeins round about them swarmd
Her Host two hundred thousand numbred is;
Mo[N]Gst thousand dangers, & ten thousand magick mights.
Mo[N]Gst thousand dangers, & ten thousand magick mights.
All these, and thousand thousands many more,
And more deformed Monsters thousand fold,
With thousand blessings she is heried;
And riue with thousand throbs thy thrilled brest;
Which thousand sprights with long enduring paines
Shall stoutly him defeat, and thousand Saxons kill.
A thousand thoughts she fashioned in her mind,
That now with thousand starres was decked fayre;
And thousand fancies bet his idle braine
Disguiz'd in thousand shapes, that none might him bewray.)
A thousand thousand naked babes attend
A thousand thousand naked babes attend
Some thousand yeares so doen they there remaine;
With thousand spots of colours queint elect,
In thousand shiuers, and so forth beside her past.
That thousand deathes me leuer were to dye,
Ten thousand wayes he cast in his confused thought.
And humbly thanked him a thousand sith,
Himselfe in thousand peeces fondly rent,
A thousand monstrous formes therein were made,
For loue in thousand monstrous formes doth oft appeare.
A thousand charmes he formerly did proue;
Yet thousand charmes could not her stedfast heart remoue.
Ten thousand thankes did yeeld her for her meed,
By thousand furies, and from thence out throwen
Had thousand women of their loue beraft,
And first laide on those Ladies thousand blames,
In which you safe I see, whom thousand late,
And thousand perills which them still awate,
And thousand vowes from bottome of his hart
Sweet springs, in which a thousand Nymphs did play;
And therein thousand payres of louers walkt,
And thousand pretious gifts worth many a pound,
Besides ten thousand monsters foule abhor'd
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
And yet besides three thousand more there were
Their setting forth, in these few thousand yeares
Her shattered ribs in thousand peeces riues,
And thousand thankes him yeeld, that had so well
A thousand feares, that loue-sicke fancies faine to fynde.
With thousand thoughts feeding her fantasie,
Besides a thousand more of such, as sings
The which did seeme a thousand tongues to haue,
Handling and turning them a thousand wayes.
And thousand thankes to Calidore for fee
Besides a thousand more, which ready bee
A thousand times him thankt, that had her death preuented.
A thousand sowres hath tempred with one sweet,
In thousand dreadful shapes doth mongst them stalke,
A thousand times embrast, and kist a thousand more.
A thousand times embrast, and kist a thousand more.
A thousand times she her embraced nere,
And therein were a thousand tongs empight,
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
And thousands moe the like, that did that dongeon fill.
All which, and thousands mo do make a loathsome life.
His cruell bow, wherewith he thousands hath dismayd.
All these, and thousand thousands many more,
'Mongst thousands good one wanton Dame to find:
And thousands like, which flowed in his braine,
The bloud hath of so many thousands shed,
And like a Serpent to the Thracian mayd.
Or any of the Thracian Nimphes in saluage chase.
Like to the Thracian Tyrant, who they say
And made that caitiues thral, the thral of wretchednesse.
And made that caitiues thral, the thral of wretchednesse.
Like captive thral two other Knights atweene,
Hath outrag'd you, and thrald your gentle make.
Him to haue bound, and thrald without delay;
To see his loued Squire into such thraldome brought.
That long captiued soules from wearie thraldome free.
To liue in thraldome of his fathers foe;
That in this thraldome Britons shall abide,
Eternall thraldome was to her more liefe,
In dolefull thraldome all his dayes to dwell?
Out of her thraldome and continuall feare?
On mighty kings and kesars, into thraldome brought.
When her from deadly thraldome he redeemed,
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
And how from thraldome vile they were vntide
Of many Nations into thraldome led,
Should wilfully be into thraldome brought,
Such thraldome or such freedome let it surely be.
And as her vassall him to thraldome tooke.
What right is it, that he should thraldome find,
Thus he long while in thraldome there remayned,
But lies in wretched thraldome, weake and wan,
They doe thy loue, forlorne in womens thraldome see.
Had shrowded bene, she did from thraldome free;
Gaue leaue vnto his ghost from thraldome bound,
But by that Tyrant is in wretched thraldome bound.
For ye into like thraldome me did throw,
What cruell hand thy wretched thraldome wrought,
Who after thraldome of the gentle Squire,
So leaue we her in wretched thraldome bound,
In bands of loue, and in sad thraldomes chayne;
Hath now made thrall to your commandement,
Can now deuise to quit a thrall from such a plight?
And made her person thrall vnto his beastly kind.
And valiant knight become a caytiue thrall,
He has them now foure yeres besiegd to make the[m] thrall.
And now in darkesome dungeon, wretched thrall,
Or weaknesse is to sinfull bands made thrall:
Thrall to that Gyants hatefull tyrannie:
Had made his caytiue thrall; againe he sayde,
But no where could he find that wofull thrall:
Then loud he cryde, I am your humble thrall.
Great mercy sure, for to enlarge a thrall,
Wilfully make thy selfe a wretched thrall,
To be her thrall, his fellow seruant vild;
Whom she did meane to make the thrall of her desire.
And threatned there to make her his eternall thrall.
In royall heart disdaining to be thrall.
Stept Braggadochio forth, and as his thrall
And now become to liue a Ladies thrall,
I rest his wretched thrall, the sad AEmylia.
And pitty much his plight, that liu'd like outcast thrall.
Him wretched thrall vnto his dongeon brought,
There with the Nymph his mother, like her thrall;
By one or other way me woefull thrall,
So had I rather to be thrall, then free;
He lately tooke, and sithence kept as thrall.
Pardon the boldnesse of thy basest thrall,
Whom a strong tyrant did vniustly thrall,
And fain'd to fly for feare of being thrall;
To be her thrall, and seruice her afford.
To thrall my looser life, or my last bale to breed.
His bodie was her thrall, his hart was freely plast.
To be so scorned of a base borne thrall,
Vnto the prison, where her hart did thrall remaine.
For yeelding so himselfe a wretched thrall,
Till he redeemed had that Lady thrall:
And taking with him, as his vanquisht thrall,
An hardie courage, like captiued thrall,
Vnto Mercilla myld for Iustice gainst the thrall.
Or is she thrall, or doth she not suruiue?
For freeing from their snares Irena thrall:
Did scorne the challenge of so base a thrall:
And sau'd from being to that caitiue thrall.
Then letting him arise like abiect thrall,
That slaine he was, or made a wretched thrall,
Beheld two such, of two such villaines thrall,
Then turning backe vnto that captiue thrall,
Or at more ease continue there his thrall:
And wondrous ioy felt in her spirits thrall:
Thus long continu'd Claribell a thrall,
Where him that witch had thralled to her will,
And thralled her in chaines with strong effort,
That haue with treason thralled vnto you
Besides the endlesse routs of wretched thralles,
Of caytiue wretched thrals, that wayled night and day.
To view the thrals, which there in bondage lay:
And forth to bring those thrals, which there he held.
To finger the fine needle and nyce thread;
And round about the pots mouth, bound the thread,
Sunning his threasure hore:
T'endow her sonne with threasure and rich store,
All the huge threasure, which the sea below
And robd the world of threasure endlesse deare,
In which he found great store of hoorded threasure,
But Paridell of loue did make no threasure,
Sends forth the winds out of his hidden threasure,
And time to steale, the threasure of mans day;
So lauishly enricht with natures threasure,
Great threasure sithence we did finde contained;
That to her selfe that threasure appertained;
But for this threasure throwne vppon his strand;
Your brothers threasure, which from him is strayd,
And so the threasure yours is Bracidas by right.
And on the threasure by that iudgement seased.
To dare not to pollute so sacred threasure,
Withouten her, whose worth aboue all threasure
And seeke to please, that now is counted wisemens threasure.
And there the keeping haue of learnings threasures,
The goodly threasures of nature appeare:
And thence did all the spoyles and threasures take,
A couetous desire with his huge threasury.
Where Mammon earst did sunne his threasury:
The coffers of her wicked threasury;
His looke was sterne, and seemed still to threat
And doubled strokes, like dreaded thunders threat:
That with his talnesse seemd to threat the skye,
And throw in raging sea with roaring threat.
And all the heauens stood still amazed with his threat.
When wintry storme his wrathfull wreck does threat,
Then gin the blustring brethren boldly threat,
But with bent lowring browes, as she would threat,
And eke the Hag with many a bitter threat,
To threat to him, that minds his chaunce t'abye?
That heauy ruine they did seeme to threat;
But soone as they approcht with deadly threat,
Ythrild with deepe disdaine of his proud threat,
Like to thicke cloudes, that threat a stormy showre,
Approching, with bold words and bitter threat,
And afterwardes affray with cruell threat,
Her mortall arrowes she at him did threat,
And cloth in womens weedes: And then with threat
The storme of fortunes frowne, or heauens threat,
Of which she vow'd with many a cursed threat,
So thought the Souldan in his follies threat,
Against his Gods, and fire to them did threat,
They turne afresh, and oft renew their former threat.
A storme approching, that doth perill threat,
And is the boast of that proud Ladies threat,
A saluage Bull, whose cruell hornes doe threat
Which booted nought for prayers, nor for threat
Him thether eke for all his fearefull threat
And death it selfe vnto himselfe did threat;
Frame thunderbolts for Ioues auengefull threate.
Deluded so, gan threaten hellish paine
And both did gnash their teeth, & both did threaten life.
And threaten batteill to the Faery knight;
That now it gan to threaten neare decay:
To heare him threaten so despightfully.
No lesse did Daunger threaten me with dread,
He gan to threaten her likewise to eat;
And eke him selfe did threaten to confound,
With darknes dred, and threatens all the world to wast.
And with sharpe threates her often did assaile,
Beholding it from far, do thinke it threates the skye.
Threates with huge ruine him to fall vpon,
For any brybes, or threates of any to be wroken.
The hollow vessell through the threatfull waue,
His threatfull pride, but did the more augment
Nor slacke her threatfull hand for daungers dout,
Which being yeelded, he his threatfull speare
She chang'd that threatfull mood, & mildly gan entreat.
Seem'd not to weigh his threatfull words at all,
And threatned vnto him the dreaded name
And threatned all his heads like flaming brands.
And threatned death with many a bloudie word;
His threatned speare, as if some new mishap
And to him threatned his hart-thrilling speare:
And threatned death with dreadfull countenaunce,
Besides he feard her wrath, and threatned shot
And them perforce withheld with threatned blade,
And oft him threatned death for his outrageous wrong.
And threatned there to make her his eternall thrall.
And threatned him with force & punishment extreme.
With th'one his foes he threatned to inuade,
And with his club me threatned to haue brayned,
From dreadfull mouth of death, which threatned sore
The comming of that so much threatned Knight,
And threatneth downe to throw his ragged rift
Threatning her angry sting, him to dismay:
But when he saw his threatning was but vaine,
And threatning high his dreadfull stroke did see,
Whom raging windes threatning to make the pray
And grimly gnash, threatning reuenge in vaine:
Threatning with greedy gripe to do him dye
All threatning death, all in straunge manner armd,
Threatning vnheedie wrecke and rash decay,
Threatning it selfe on them to ruinate,
As threatning to deuoure all, that his powre despise.
Threatning the point of her auenging blade,
Threatning to swallow vp my fearefull life?
Threatning into his life to make a breach,
Threatning to strike, vnlesse he would withstand:
And then came Daunger threatning hidden dread,
And with bold vaunts, and ydle threatning bad
Threatning to chastize me, as doth t'a chyld pertaine.
And threatning his sharpe clawes, now wanting powre to straine.
Threatning to yoke them tow & tame their corage stout.
And bet abacke, threatning in vaine to bite,
And after him full many threatnings threw,
Now with faire speches, now with threatnings sterne,
Thus long the dore with rage and threats he bet,
What meane these bloudy vowes, and idle threats,
Kindles Reuenge, and threats his rusty knife;
Somtimes with threats, somtimes with hope of gaine,
From the high mountaines, threats to ouerflow
With cruell threats, his passage through the ford to let.
Now with sharpe threats; but threats the more increast their mood.
Now with sharpe threats; but threats the more increast their mood.
Threw many threats, if they the towne did win,
And when in wrath he threats the worlds decay,
Nought fear'd the childe his lookes, ne yet his threats,
And threats his horns, and bellowes like the thonder,
And mixed threats among, and much vnto her vowed.
And thred-bare cote, and cobled shoes he ware,
The eldest of three brethren, all three bred
The eldest of three brethren, all three bred
And thrise three times did fast from any bit:
When two of three her Nephews are so fowle forlorne?
His three deformed heads did lay along,
And catching vp in hast his three square shield,
The hight of three the tallest sonnes of mortall seed.
Three miles it might be easie heard around,
And Ecchoes three answerd it selfe againe:
That three yardes deepe a furrow vp did throw:
For now three Moones haue cha[n]ged thrice their hew,
The mother of three daughters, well vpbrought
On which the thrise three learned Ladies play
So leaue they take of Coelia, and her daughters three.
And of three furlongs does but litle lacke;
Three ranckes of yron teeth enraunged were,
And three mens strength vnto the stroke he layd;
Full measured three quarters of her yeare,
And thrise three times had fild her crooked hornes,
Therein three sisters dwelt of sundry sort,
The children of one sire by mothers three;
Straunge sort of fight, three valiaunt knights to see
Three combats ioyne in one, and to darraine
For now three dayes of men were full outwrought,
And with his goodly sisters, Graces three;
Three times more furious, and more puissaunt,
But three the chiefest, and of greatest powre,
In which there dwelt three honorable sages,
Three ages, such as mortall men contriue,
These three in these three roomes did sundry dwell,
These three in these three roomes did sundry dwell,
But Alma thence the[m] led to th'hindmost roome of three.
But those three monstrous stones doe most excell
He left three sonnes, his famous progeny,
But three faire daughters, which were well vptraind,
Three sonnes he dying left, all vnder age;
From whence eftsoones arriued here three hoyes
Soone after which, three hundred Lordes he slew
The one of which had two heads, th'other three:
He left three sonnes, the which in order raynd,
Aboue three furlongs, taking his full course,
That all the three thereat woxe much afrayd,
Whose depth exceeded not three cubits hight,
Ne did she stay, till three on ground she layd,
Scarse do they spare to one or two or three,
Then taking thrise three haires from off her head,
Now haue three Moones with borrow'd brothers light,
So beene they three three sundry wayes ybent.
So beene they three three sundry wayes ybent.
three fosters Timias wound,
Tho to his brethren came: for they were three
That seeing now the onely last of three,
They three be dead with shame, the Squire liues with renowne.
Three hundred pledges for my good desartes,
And thrise three hundred thanks for my good partes
For onely three they were disposd so well,
And yet three yeares I now abroad haue strayd,
The knight) inquire of thee, what were those three,
Thus long they three together traueiled,
Three nights in one, they say, that for her sake
All three to each vnlike, yet all made in one mould.
For which the three faire Goddesses did striue:
They by consent should chose the stoutest three,
Amongst those knights there were three brethren bold,
Three bolder brethren neuer were yborne,
That bore three such, three such not to be fond;
That bore three such, three such not to be fond;
All three as one, the first hight Priamond,
These three did loue each other dearely well,
Which did her powre into three parts diuyde;
Like three faire branches budding farre and wide,
These three so noble babes to bring forth at one clap.
Got these three louely babes, that prov'd three cha[m]pions bold.
Got these three louely babes, that prov'd three cha[m]pions bold.
To the three fatall sisters house she went.
His line, which is the eldest of the three,
Them found all three according to their kynd:
The battell twixt three brethren, with
The which in seeking for her children three
These three that hardie chalenge tooke in hand,
Soone after did the brethren three aduance,
For lifes succession in those brethren three.
Once thinke to match three such on equall cost,
Three such as able were to match a puissant host.
But till the horned moone three courses did expire.
And of vs three to morrow he will sure eate one.
When all three kinds of loue together meet,
And there the three renowmed brethren were,
These three faire sons, which being the[n]ce forth powrd
In three great riuers ran, and many countreis scowrd.
And yet besides three thousand more there were
So shall you by one gift saue all vs three aliue.
Within three daies (quoth hee) as I do here,
How that three warlike persons did appeare,
He had three sonnes, all three like fathers sonnes,
He had three sonnes, all three like fathers sonnes,
And had three bodies in one wast empight,
And th'armes and legs of three, to succour him in fight.
Through his three bodies powre, in one combynd;
But as he nigher drew, three knights he spyde,
As three great Culuerings for battrie bent,
Through his three double hands thrise multiplyde,
Through all three bodies he him strooke attonce;
That all the three attonce fell on the plaine:
So now all three one sencelesse lumpe remaine,
Three times, as in defiance, there he strooke;
And in three battailes did so deadly daunt,
Three mightie en'mies did him most despight,
Three mightie ones, and cruell minded eeke,
There his three foes shrowded in guilefull shade,
Him well behoued so; for his three foes
Whom soone as his three enemies did vew,
Three other Ladies did both daunce and sing,
And in the middest of those same three, was placed
But most of all, those three did her with gifts endew.
Those three to men all gifts of grace do graunt,
